ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about cities, the different elements of a city, and the direction cities are going as well as how certain events or aspects shape a city and shape us.
How to think about cities, their interactions, and their futures. It was great to think about cities both from a historical theory perspective and the present-day situation.

I learned about major urban studies design concepts (e.g. the 15 minute city, eyes on the street, mixed-use design) and the history of cities / suburbs. We also examined case studies across a variety of cities (Abu Dhabi, Songdo, NYC, So Paulo, etc.)

I learnt a lot about the numerous dimensions that go into city planning  infrastructure, security, community, sustainability, transportation, retail, etc. The content in this class was very interesting and applicable to people from all fields!
In this class, we discussed many of the different layers of governance and planning as well as the different networks of collaboration in many present-day cities.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thoroughly enjoyed the course. I thought the reading load was spot on and the readings were informative. I valued discussion in class.
I loved how many themes and topics this course covered! Listening to the different real-world applications and experiences that they had was very engaging too.

Strengths - The material was super interesting and the lectures were amazing. I loved learning about the various features of a great city and what steps people are taking to make cities better. I also appreciated that we had a historical perspective as well, and the extent to which we examined the relationship between the city and the suburbs. 
Weaknesses - Sometimes, I felt the professors assumed we had more urban design background than we did, and as a result, students got very quiet during discussion because we werent sure how to approach their questions.

Strengths: the topics are super interesting, and Mat and Manasvi are super chill and just great. The papers are graded super fairly and the workload is manageable. 

Weaknesses: some of the readings are pretty dense, long and boring, even though the topics themselves and the class discussion is interesting. If youre good at skimming, youll be fine!

The course was fascinating and the topics were really great. I do think that the course could have been a bit more interactive for people with experiences beyond just the Global North. Even though I consistently did the readings to the best of my ability, I often felt that our discussions left me feeling that I had very little to contribute. I also think the lectures could have been a bit more interactive, involving breakout rooms or activities that would make sure that everyone was involved.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All the course practices allowed for good virtual engagement.
The virtual seminar format was okay  definitely not great and class engagement wasnt super high, but the best we could do given the circumstances.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely! A wonderful class with wonderful professors. I learned a lot and had fun while doing so.
Yes - Its a fun seminar and I really liked the opportunity to just learn about something interesting for the sake of learning about it.
Absolutely. This is a very well structured course. Readings were engaging and class discussion was always fun. Honestly one of the best courses Ive taken at Yale.

Yes! Learning about how cities function is so important and so interesting, irrespective of what field you come from. Everyone has something to say on this topic and having classmates who have lived in or experienced a wide range of cities makes it really interesting. Even if you dont come from a big city, take the class if you can! Mat and Manasvi are great and super understanding about student workload, etc.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
